The '''Global Energy International Prize''' is one of the world’s largest prizes and is awarded to leading scientists regardless of their nationality, citizenship, religious beliefs, race, sex, or financial status. The main goal of the Prize is to provide stimulus for resolving global energy and ecological problems which are important to all humanity. The Prize is awarded for breakthroughs, discoveries and the large-scale achievements in the field of energy. The Prize is worth US$1 million, and has been called the "[[Nobel Prize]] for power technology".<ref>{{cite book |title=Innovative Minds: A Look Inside Siemens' Idea Machine |last=Eberl |first=Ulrich |coauthors=Jöerg Puma |page=110 |year=2007 |publisher=[[John Wiley and Sons]] |isbn=9783895782992 }}</ref>
The Global Energy International Prize was founded in 2002 in Russia<ref>{{cite news |title=Two Russians and American Win Prize |url=http://www.sptimes.ru/index.php?action_id=2&story_id=817 |work=[[The St. Petersburg Times]] |date=2 June 2004 |accessdate=25 March 2010 }}</ref> with the support of Gazprom, Surgutneftegaz, and FGC UES – the largest oil companies in Russia. Since the inception of the Prize, 20 of the most important scientists from eight countries – UK, Germany, Iceland, Canada, Russia, the USA, France, and Japan – have been awarded the prize. More than 1,700 recognised scientists from 45 countries participate in the nomination process.
The members of the entire management (the Executive Directorate, the Expert Commission, the International Award Committee, and the Board of Trustees) participate directly in the Award Process.
Stage I is the nomination process. Beginning 1 September, numbered forms are sent out to a base of nominating scientists whose right to nominate has been confirmed by the International Award Committee. From 1 October to 1 March, nominations are accepted for the Prize. These nominations consist of descriptions of projects which have achieved significant results. Only the highest-rated scientists may nominate candidates: Nobel Prize Laureates for physics or chemistry, past Laureates of the Global Energy Prize, and Laureates of the Kyoto, Max Planck, and Wolf prizes have the right to make nominations. Scientists who are involved in the Global Energy Foundation forfeit the right to make nominations. In this way, the Expert Commission and the International Award Committee can remain unbiased and effective in choosing the most worthy Laureates.
Stage II. In the period from 1 March to 1 April, the Expert Commission of the Global Energy International Prize, which includes leading scientists, conducts a preliminary selection of works. The makeup of the Expert Commission is not announced in order to eliminate the risk of influence being exercised on the choice of works provided to the International Committee for the final decision. The members of the Expert Commission choose the top five works, from which the International Committee chooses three Laureates.
Stage III. Out of the five works, the members of the International Award Committee choose three Laureates to be awarded the Global Energy International Prize. The meeting of the International Award Committee and choice of Laureates takes place in April. The 2010 International Committee comprised 35 of the most important scientists and public figures from 13 countries: UK, Hungary, Germany, India, Iceland, Spain, Kazakhstan, Canada, Russia, the USA, Tanzania, France, and Japan. On 15 April 2010, a meeting of the full quorum of the International Award Committee will be held in Moscow, the capital of Russia, for the purpose of determining the Prize Laureates. On 16 April 2010, the names of the 2010 Laureates will be announced at a press conference.
The Award Ceremony will be held in June in St. Petersburg (Russia). According to tradition, the President of the Russian Federation Dmitry Medvedev<ref>{{cite news |title=Russian president awards Global Energy prizes |url=http://en.rian.ru/russia/20090605/155179538.html |work=[[Ria Novosti]] |date=5 June 2009 |accessdate=25 March 2010 }}</ref> will present the Prize to the Laureates.

{{unreferenced}} {{essay}} {{notability}} In this article we cover some of the principal issues concerning the Translation Management Systems. We make a quick overview of the translation management systems. We present and analyze the ontram translation management system with its functionalities, versions and advantages.
== Introduction to the Translation Management Systems ==
The Translation Management Systems are software solutions build to integrate all the different aspects of a translation process. The user defines a number of workflow rules and the software will automatically manage the interaction between all the different stakeholders and tasks of the project. The objective of these systems is to automate as much as possible all the activities involved in the creation and management of the multilingual content. This automation will finish with many of the most current problems that arise during a translation project such as delays or files losses.
The Translation Management Systems can be client-based or web-based. The most modern ones are web-based because in that way the interface is accessible from every computer connected to the internet making it much more flexible. The most common activities included in these systems are change detection, content extraction and packaging, file preparation, customizable workflows, online and offline translation tools, facilitated translation review, TM management, content delivery and reintegration, metrics and reporting, etc. The main objective of a translation management system is to reduce the localisation costs, reduce the time to market and improve the translation quality.
== Ontram Translation Management System ==
Ontram is a web-based Translation Management System whose principal modules are: * Data filters * Translation Memory * Preview Function * Workflow engine * Deadline control and monitoring * Change Management
They are media-neutral and available to any persons involved in the translation and review processes via a very simply operated web interface. Ontram is specifically designed for use by multilingual operating companies - and covering both product as well as technical communication.
Ontram enables browser-based translation and editing of texts independent of the data format of the source documents. The translation memory, preview function, integrated change management and other productivity functions support the user, document the editing status and ensure a seamless co-operation of the project participants.
Core application and user interface are standardised for all data formats. The document that has to be translated is analysed by a specific data format import filter and the content is separated from the layout. Subsequently, media-neutral content processing is carried out according to the processing steps defined by the workflow. After the translation of the document, the export filter ensures that the generated language versions are converted to the original format. In the translation mode the users can see the source and target language in one window and the [[Translation memory]] provides translation suggestions. The data handling by ontram follows an easy and proven workflow. This ensures that users only process the relevant or required contents.
The advantages of the ontram Translation Management System compared with a conventional TMS are: * Project management, localization and translation in one system * Easy-to-use interface for all formats * Central status monitoring, billing and process management * Fully integrated Workflow System * Integration in existing system environments and processes (e.g. Content Management Systems (CMS), e-Learning systems, Editing Systems, Databases, PIM's and ERP's)
== Fields of Application ==
Ontram can be used everywhere where contents have to be localized regularly. Also when existing processes and systems already support multilingualism, it is often useful to store the translation and review processes in a professional translation system. The interfaces support the exchange of content data and workflow information. The savings potential compared to traditional translation processes is enormous.
The start and end of the ontram workflow in the process chain, the project-specific workflow steps and the associated responsibilities and roles can be defined individually. Translation tasks are unequivocally assigned to the processors, which avoids any unclear status information. The system automatically compares the actual and target situation. In the event of deviations, ontram initiates previously defined escalation steps.
Ontram can be integrated in the operations as an intelligent web service, for instance based on [[SOAP]] or [[CORBA]] if allowed by existing system structures. As soon as it is established that the contents have to be processed, they are automatically transferred to ontram and translated and reviewed with the aid of ontram and then transferred back automatically.
If the same or a similar text has already been translated, ontram recognises this automatically and provides the translator with the available translations. If the translation is a 100% match of the text, the text can be copied after a short verification. Any deviations are shown so that the necessary changes can be made. In addition to a reduction of the project costs, it also leads to a standardisation of the translation style and considerably reduces subsequent review costs. Ontram also provides high quality assurance, spell checking, projects deadline management and changes management.
The supported data formats compatibility of ontram currently includes: * Adobe FrameMaker * Adobe InDesign * CMS-XML formats * CSV * Flash * HTML * Microsoft Access, Microsoft Excel, Microsoft PowerPoint, Microsoft Word * Office Open XML * OpenDocument * QuarkXPress * SCORM (WBT) * TYPO3 * XLIFF * XML

[[Image:Being digital negroponte.gif|thumb|right|''Being Digital'''s front cover]]
'''''Being Digital''''' is a [[non-fiction]] book about digital technologies and their possible future by technology author [[Nicholas Negroponte]]. It was originally published in [[January 1995]] by [[Random House|Vintage Publishing]].
''Being Digital'' provides a general history of several [[digital media]] technologies, many that Negroponte himself was directly involved in developing. Negroponte analyzes the advantages and disadvantages of the technologies (such as his belief that [[High-definition television]] wastes broadcasting power), and tries to predict how the technologies will evolve. Negroponte presents a strong belief that humanity is inevitably headed towards a future where everything that can will be digitalized (be it newspapers, entertainment, or sex). This leads Negroponte to a quote repeated often in promoting and explaining the book's material, that the book is made of "unwieldy atoms" that will probably be replaced by a digital copy by the time anyone reads the book. Several [[e-book]]s exist of ''Being Digital'', making the quote rather prophetic.
Being Digital also introduced the "[[Daily Me]]" concept of a virtual daily newspaper customized for an individual's tastes. This prediction has also come to pass with the advent of [[web feed]]s and [[Web portal#Personal portals|personal web portals]].
==Bits and Atoms== Negroponte writes a lot about the idea of bits and atoms. He says that bits are the smallest form of information on a computer. He believes that many bits combined make up information on a computer. Digital music, ebooks, emails and many other types of information on the computer are made of bits. He also writes about atoms. Atoms make up physical, tangible objects such as CDs, books and letters. He believes that in the future all forms of information that are now made of Atoms (books, CDs, etc.) will eventually be turned into bits. ==Negroponte Switch== It is his idea that digital information that is going through the ground (wires, cables) will eventually be through the air. Also, the digital information that is going through the air (ethere) will later be going through the ground. Negroponte called this "trading places," but it gained the name the "Negroponte Switch." ==Technological Interface== Negroponte believes in different forms of interface than we currently have. He believes that the mouse was an mediocre interface for point and click, and horrible for drawing. The interfaces were touch-screen technology and voice recognition software. The IPhone and other touch-screen software proved him correct that touch-screen technology would be a future form of interface. ==References== * ''Being Digital'', 1995. ISBN 0-679-43919-6 * [http://archives.obs-us.com/obs/english/books/nn/bdintro.htm ''Being Digital''] e-book by Cyberdock, 2005.
==External links== * [http://www.cdli.ca/~elmurphy/emurphy/digital.html Review and overview of ''Being Digital''], by Elizabeth Murphy, 1996. *[http://docs.google.com/View?revision=_latest&docID=dk6crxf_4gqtp3d A few quotes from ''Being Digital'']

{{Essay-like|article|date=April 2010}} '''Business Augmentation Services''' is a specialized set of services for managing and nurturing a company in the business of technology and assuring steep growth with clients and sales prospects. It involves using business concepts like branding and strategic planning as well as [[Disruptive Technology]] to organize, automate, and generate business processes—principally [[product design]] and [[sales]] activities, but also those for [[marketing]],[[patents]] ( [[Intellectual Asset Management|IAM]] ), [[customer service]], and [[technical support]]. The overall goals are to innovate in "360 degrees", in other words, to utilize technology and business ideas in unison and simultaneously to find, attract, and win new clients, nurture and retain those the company already has, entice former clients back into the fold, and reduce the costs of marketing, client service, production, and design all while exponentially increasingly the value of the company and it's products in the customer's eyes. The service set was created based on the belief the business is driven by technology<ref name=key>Keystone Strategy, Inc. (6 June 2009) [http://www.microsoft.com/business/enterprise/itdrivesgrowth.mspx Keystone Strategy, Inc., research study: Information technology drives growth Published in March 13, 2006]</ref> Once a company embraces this service set, specialized individuals well-versed in these concepts become necessary to execute them. Once simply a label for a category of software tools, today, it generally denotes a company-wide business strategy embracing all technology as well as client-facing departments and even beyond. When an implementation is effective, people, processes, and technology work in synergy to increase profitability, and reduce operational costs.<ref name=roleit>"The role of information technology in the profit and cost efficiency improvements..." (2005) [http://www.accessmylibrary.com/article-1G1-149213894/role-information-technology-profit.html The role of information technology in the profit and cost efficiency improvements of the banking sector.]</ref>
===Benefits=== These tools have been shown to help companies attain these objectives: *Streamlined sales and marketing processes *New markets and instant, assured leadership in these markets through Patents *Higher sales productivity *Added [[cross-selling]] and [[up-selling]] opportunities *Improved service, loyalty, and retention *Increased [[Product (business)|Product]][[Research and development|Development]] efficiency (the objective is always a 10x increase) *Better profiling and targeting as well as new customer profiling and targeting *Reduced expenses (the objective is a 10x decrease as shown in [[Disruptive Technology]]) *Increased current [[market share]] *Higher overall profitability
===Related Trends=== New trends are beginning to take hold in this field. Due to the abundance of technical knowledge, the reduction in cost for said knowledge as well as the growing need for velocity when approaching a new market, companies are beginning to turn into "one-stop-shops" for business and technological services, requiring professionals skilled in both fields. Perhaps the most notable trend has been the growth of tools delivered via the Web, also known as [[cloud computing]] and [[software as a service]] (SaaS). In contrast with traditional on-premises software, cloud-computing applications are sold by subscription, accessed via a secure Internet connection, and displayed on a Web browser. Companies don’t incur the initial capital expense of purchasing software; nor must they buy and maintain IT hardware to run it on. As with all business fields affected by globalization, many companies around the world have created a niche as BAS groups and currently the new companies are creating value in the stagnated field of outsourced business and IT services.
===Challenges=== Despite the benefits, many companies are still not fully leveraging these tools and services, mostly because the areas that deal with business and technology very often are separate entities, and as such may not fully understand each other. BAS is a set of defined services that fuse these previously incongruous areas into processes that have an impact that has yet to be fully understood. To align marketing,engineering, design, sales, and service to best serve the customer while reducing costs, the company needs to reconcile these areas through BAS, which requires juxtaposing previously irreconcilable objectives effectively .<ref name=habib>USING TECHNOLOGY TO REDUCE COST [http://www.habibbank.com/common/articles/article63.html using technology to reduce costs]</ref>
BAS Tools, services and work-flows can be complex to implement, especially for large enterprises. Previously these tools were generally limited. Software solutions then expanded to embrace things such as design needs, engineering, deal tracking, territories, opportunities, and at the sales pipeline itself. Next came the advent of tools for other client-facing business functions, as described below. These technologies have been, and still are, offered as on-premises software that companies purchase and run on their own IT infrastructure. Now, companies are emerging to provide these solutions exclusively. In effect, these BAS houses are experts in a relatively new field and as such are not yet widely used by more traditional corporations.
Often, implementations are fragmented; isolated initiatives by individual departments to address their own needs. Systems that start disunited usually stay that way: siloed thinking and decision processes frequently lead to separate and incompatible systems, and dysfunctional processes, not to mention weak product lines and low market awareness.
==Previous Types/variations== ===Sales Force Automation=== A [[sales force automation]] (SFA) system provides an array of capabilities to streamline all phases of the sales process, minimizing the time that sales representatives need to spend on manual data entry and administration. This allows them to successfully pursue more clients in a shorter amount of time than would otherwise be possible. At the heart of SFA is a [[contact management system]] for tracking and recording every stage in the sales process for each prospective client, from initial contact to final disposition. Many SFA applications also include insights into opportunities, territories, sales forecasts and work-flow automation, quote generation, and product knowledge. Newly-emerged priorities are modules for Web 2.0 e-commerce and pricing.
===Marketing=== Systems for marketing (also known as [[marketing automation]]) help the enterprise identify and target its best clients and generate qualified leads for the sales team. A key marketing capability is tracking and measuring multichannel campaigns, including email, search, social media, and direct mail. Metrics monitored include clicks, responses, leads, deals, and revenue. As marketing departments are increasingly obliged to demonstrate revenue impact, today’s systems typically include features for measuring the [[Overall Rate of Return|ROI]] of campaigns.
===Disruptive IT Service and Support=== Recognizing that disruptive technology is an important differentiation, organizations are increasingly turning to technology platforms to help them improve their clients’ experience while aiming to increase efficiency and minimize costs.<ref name=disruptive>PC world magazine (18 March 2008) [http://www.pcworld.com/article/143474/the_10_most_disruptive_technology_combinations.html The 10 Most Disruptive Technology Combinations]</ref> Even so, a 2009 study revealed that only 39% of corporate executives believe their employees have the right tools and authority to solve client problems.“.<ref>Strativity Group, Inc. (2009) [http://www.strativity.com/products/2009-05-26.aspx Global Customer Experience Management Benchmark Study]</ref>
===Analytics=== Relevant analytics capabilities are often interwoven into applications in sales, marketing, and service. These features can be complemented and augmented with links to separate, purpose-built applications for analytics and business intelligence. Sales analytics let companies monitor and understand client actions and preferences, through sales forecasting, data quality, and dashboards that graphically display [[key performance indicators]] (KPIs).
Marketing applications generally come with [[predictive analytics]] to improve segmentation and targeting, and features for measuring the effectiveness of online, offline, and search marketing campaign Web analytics have evolved significantly from their starting point of merely tracking mouse clicks on Web sites. By evaluating “buy signals,” marketers can see which prospects are most likely to transact and also identify those who are bogged down in a sales process and need assistance. Marketing and finance personnel also use analytics to assess the value of multi-faceted programs as a whole.
These types of analytics are increasing in popularity as companies demand greater visibility into the performance of call centers and other support channels, in order to correct problems before they affect satisfaction levels. Support-focused applications typically include dashboards similar to those for sales, plus capabilities to measure and analyze response times, service quality, agent performance, and the frequency of various issues.
===Integrated/Collaborative=== Departments within enterprises—especially large enterprises—tend to function in their own little worlds.<ref name=mckinseycolab>Using technology to improve workforce collaboration (27 october 2009) [http://whatmatters.mckinseydigital.com/internet/using-technology-to-improve-workforce-collaboration Using technology to improve workforce collaboration]</ref> Traditionally, inter-departmental interaction and collaboration have been infrequent and rivalries not uncommon. More recently, the development and adoption of the tools and services has fostered greater fluidity and cooperation among sales, service, and marketing. This finds expression in the concept of collaborative systems which uses technology to build bridges between departments.
For example, feedback from a [[technical support]] center can enlighten marketers about specific services and product features clients are asking for. Reps, in their turn, want to be able to pursue these opportunities without the time-wasting burden of re-entering records and contact data into a separate SFA system. Conversely, lack of integration can have negative consequences: if a system isn’t adopted and integrated among all departments, several sources might contact the same clients for an identical purpose.{{Citation needed|date=December 2009}} Owing to these factors, many of the top-rated and most popular products come as integrated suites.
===Small Business=== Basic client service can be accomplished by a contact manager system, an integrated solution that lets organizations and individuals efficiently track and record interactions, including emails, documents, jobs, faxes, scheduling, and more. This kind of solution is gaining traction with even very small businesses, thanks to the ease and time savings of handling client contact through a centralized application rather than several different pieces of software, each with its own data collection system. {{Citation needed|date=December 2009}} In contrast these tools usually focus on accounts rather than individual contacts. They also generally include opportunity insight for tracking sales pipelines plus added functionality for marketing and service. As with larger enterprises, small businesses are finding value in online solutions, especially for mobile and [[telecommuting]] workers.
===Social Media=== [[Social media]] sites like [[Twitter]] and [[Facebook]] are greatly amplifying the voice of people in the marketplace and are predicted to have profound and far-reaching effects on the ways companies manage their clients, even to the family level.<ref name=svcp>sjsu.edu(1998) [http://www.sjsu.edu/depts/anthropology/svcp/SVCPcosa.html Technology and Social Change: The Effects on Family and Community]</ref> This is because people are using these social media sites to share opinions and experiences on companies, products, and services. As social media isn’t moderated or censored, individuals can say anything they want about a company or brand, whether pro or con.
Increasingly, companies are looking to gain access to these conversations and take part in the dialogue. More than a few systems are now integrating to social networking sites. Social media promoters cite a number of business advantages, such as using online communities as a source of high-quality leads and a vehicle for [[crowd sourcing]] solutions to client-support problems. Companies can also leverage client stated habits and preferences to personalize and even “hyper-target” their sales and marketing communications.
Some analysts take the view that business-to-business marketers should proceed cautiously when weaving social media into their business processes. These observers recommend careful market research to determine if and where the phenomenon can provide measurable benefits for client interactions, sales, and support.<ref>Harvard business review (2010) [http://blogs.hbr.org/cs/2009/11/six_social_media_trends.html Six Social Media Trends for 2010]</ref>
===Non-profit and Membership-based=== Systems for non-profit and membership-based organizations help track constituents and their involvement in the organization. Capabilities typically include tracking the following: fund-raising, demographics, membership levels, membership directories, volunteering and communications with individuals.
Many include tools for identifying potential donors based on previous donations and participation. In light of the growth of social networking tools, there may be some overlap between social/community driven tools and non-profit/membership tools.
==Strategy== Choosing and implementing a system is a major undertaking. For enterprises of any appreciable size, a complete and detailed plan is required to obtain the funding, resources, and company-wide support that can make the initiative successful. Benefits must be defined, risks assessed, and cost quantified in three general areas:
*Processes: Though these systems have many technological components, business processes lie at its core. It can be seen as a more client-centric way of doing business, enabled by technology that consolidates and intelligently distributes pertinent information about clients, sales, marketing effectiveness, responsiveness, and market trends. Therefore, before choosing a technology platform, a company needs to analyze its business workflows and processes; some will likely need re-engineering to better serve the overall goal of winning and satisfying clients. Moreover, planners need to determine the types of client information that are most relevant, and how best to employ them. *People: For an initiative to be effective, an organization must convince its staff that change is good and that the new technology and workflows will benefit employees as well as clients. Senior executives need to be strong and visible advocates who can clearly state and support the case for change. Collaboration, teamwork, and two-way communication should be encouraged across hierarchical boundaries, especially with respect to process improvement.<ref>TechTarget (2009) [http://searchcrm.techtarget.com/feature/CRM-strategy-checklist-Planning-for-CRM-and-customer-service-success?offer=briefcaseCRM Strategy Checklist: Planning for CRM and Customer Service Success]</ref> *Technology: In evaluating technology, key factors include alignment with the company’s business process strategy and goals; the ability to deliver the right data to the right employees; and sufficient ease of use that users won’t balk. Platform selection is best undertaken by a carefully chosen group of executives who understand the business processes to be automated as well as the various software issues. Depending upon the size of the company and the breadth of data, choosing an application can take anywhere from a few weeks to a year or more.
==Implementation== ===Implementation Issues=== Dramatic increases in revenue, higher rates of client satisfaction, and significant savings in operating costs are some of the benefits to an enterprise. Proponents emphasize that technology should be implemented only in the context of careful strategic and operational planning.<ref>{{cite book|title='''Passionate and Profitable'''|author= Lior Arussy|publisher=John Wiley & Sons, Inc.|year=2005|chapter=Understanding the Fatal Mistakes}}</ref> Implementations almost invariably fall short when one or more facets of this prescription are ignored:
*Poor planning: Initiatives can easily fail when efforts are limited to choosing and deploying software, without an accompanying rationale, context, and support for the workforce.<ref>{{cite journal|title='''Avoid the Four Perils of CRM'''|coauthors=, Darrell K.Rigby; Frederick F. Reichheld, Phil Schefter,|journal=Harvard Business Review}}</ref> In other instances, enterprises simply automate flawed client-facing processes rather than redesign them according to best practices. *Poor integration: For many companies, integrations are piecemeal initiatives that address a glaring need: improving a particular client-facing process or two or automating a favored sales or client support channel. Such “point solutions” offer little or no integration or alignment with a company’s overall strategy. They offer a less than complete client view and often lead to unsatisfactory user experiences. *Towards a solution: overcoming siloed thinking. Experts advise organizations to recognize the immense value of integrating their client-facing operations. In this view, internally-focused, department-centric views should be discarded in favor of reorienting processes toward information-sharing across marketing, design, engineering, sales, and service. For example, sales representatives need to know about current issues and relevant marketing promotions before attempting to cross-sell to a specific client. Marketing staff should be able to leverage client information from sales and service to better target campaigns and offers. And support agents require quick and complete access to a client’s sales and service history.
===Adoption Issues=== Enterprises need to address and overcome persistent adoption challenges. Specialists offer these recommendations for boosting adoptions rates and coaxing users to blend these tools into their daily work-flow:
*Choose a system that’s easy to use: All solutions are not created equal. Some vendors offer more user-friendly applications than others, and simplicity should be as important a decision factor as functionality. *Focusing on the client's client: it is sometimes difficult to define the "client's client", and as the central goal of BAS houses is to please exactly this group, this presents an issue with uninitiated users of BAS. *Choose the right capabilities: Employees need to know that time invested in learning and usage will yield personal advantages. If not, they will work around or ignore the system. *Provide training: Changing the way people work is no small task, and help is usually a requirement. Even with today’s more usable systems, many staffers still need assistance with learning and adoption.

[[File:Wifire.PNG|thumb|alt=Alt text|The Wi-Fire]]
'''The Wi-Fire'''
The [http://www.hfield.com/ Wi-Fire by hField] is a compact, range-extending [[Wireless USB specification|USB]] device that allows users to access [[Wi-Fi|wireless Internet]] connections. The company claims that a connection can be reached and maintained from up to 1,000 feet away. This capability is more than three times the range of a standard internal wireless adapter.<sup>[http://inventorspot.com/articles/review_new_wifire_extends_wifi_r_8559/ 1 ]</sup>
The Wi-Fire uses a powerful [[directional antenna]], a highly sensitive [[Receiver (radio)|receiver]] and proprietary software to find and enhance normal WiFi signals. A computer's internal wireless card is not as sensitive and cannot detect as many networks or maintain as strong of a connection. Even at low signal strengths the Wi-Fire is faster, more reliable and more consistently strong, than an internal wireless card.
"The palm-size antenna provides faster and more solid connections by combining a sensitive decoding [[Electronic circuit|circuit]] with a directional antenna that [[Amplifier|amplifies]] the signal. Pointing the antenna toward the base station or [[router]] can produce a signal that may be two or three times greater than one from a traditional antenna buried in a laptop. That difference [in signal strength] can turn a back room or the most remote corner of the pool deck into a fully functional Web-browsing location." <sup>[http://www.nytimes.com/2007/12/06/technology/personaltech/06antenna.html?_r=1&scp=1&sq=wi-fire&st=cse/ ''The New York Times'']</sup>
==OS Compatibility== *[[Windows XP]], [[Windows Vista|Vista]] <sup>[http://www.engadget.com/2007/11/06/hfield-intros-vista-compatible-wi-fire-long-range-wifi-adapter/]</sup> and [[Windows 7|7]]. *Mac <sup>[http://www.engadget.com/2010/01/20/wi-fire-long-range-wifi-adapater-gets-updated-mac-software/]</sup> OS X [[Tiger|10.4 (Tiger)]], Mac OS X [[Leopard|10.5 (Leopard)]] and Mac OS X [[Mac OS X Snow Leopard|10.6 (Snow Leopard)]] *[[gnuLinEx|Linux]] (with kernel 2.6.24 and forward)
==Product Numbers== *HFWFG200 (FCC, IC, All other non-CE) *HFWFG200-CE (20dBm Max Power for CE regulated countries)
==Wireless Specifications== *Average maximum power ([[Equivalent isotropically radiated power|EIRP]]): 27+ dBm *Minimum Receive Power: -96 [[dBm]] *IEE 802.11 b/g protocols *Frequency Range: 2.421 - 2.4835 [[Hertz|GHz]] *Security: [[Wired Equivalent Privacy|WEP]], [[Wi-Fi Protected Access|WPA, WPA2, WPAPSK, WPA2PSK]] *Media Access Control: CSMA/CA with [[Transmission Control Protocol|ACK]] *Certification: [[Federal Communications Commission|FCC]], [[IC3|IC]], [[CE Mark|CE]] (when so labeled) *Channels: North America -11 channels, Rest of the world -13 channels
==Physical Specifications== *2.8 ounces (80g) *4L x 0.55W (average) x 2.25 inches (102 x 14 x 57 mm) *USB 2.0 *5V DC (from USB Port) *The Wi-Fire draws very little power from a [[laptop]] battery.
==Operating the Wi-Fire== #To set up the Wi-Fire you must simply install the Connection Manager [[CD-ROM|(CD-Rom)]] and then plug the Wi-Fire into an available [[Universal Serial Bus|USB]] port. #To maximize the [[signal strength]] for a desired network, just rotate the directional antenna (the large flat component of the product) until the signal reaches its maximum strength. ##To simply select the strongest available network – public access or private and encrypted – after plugging in the Wi-Fire, rotate the antenna until you detect a strong signal from a network you are able to connect to, and then click connect in the connection manager. #Once a desired network is connected to, the most effective way to maximize [[throughput]] is to make sure that the antenna is pointed in the direction of the strongest signal (which may not necessarily be in the exact direction of the wireless signal source).
==What the Wi-Fire does== ===See More Wireless Connections=== The Wi-Fire Connection Manager reveals all available [[Wireless network|networks]] in the area <sup>[http://realgadgetreviews.blogspot.com/2009/09/hfield-technologies-wi-fire-review-long.html]</sup>. It allows the user to see more connections than would otherwise be visible without the Wi-Fire. # You are able to receive Wi-Fi almost anywhere you travel. <sup>[http://www.pcmag.com/article2/0,2817,2254449,00.asp]</sup> # You will never have to move closer to a [[Hotspot (Wi-Fi)|wifi hotspot]]. <sup>[http://www.engadget.com/2009/09/02/wi-fire-long-range-wifi-adapter-hands-on-and-impressions/]</sup>
===Faster Speeds for Internet Browsing=== The Wi-Fire provides higher speeds at lower signal strengths than your typical internal adapter. Independent reviewers have agreed that the Wi-Fire beats [[IEEE 802.11n-2009|802.11n]] products in range and in speed at [http://www.maximumpc.com/article/hfield_technologies_wifire_wifi_adapter/ long distances.]
The Wi-Fire itself is compatible with all [[IEEE 802.11b-1999|802.11b]][[IEEE 802.11g-2003|/g]] protocols.
===Surfing the Web=== The product allows the user to surf the web, tap remote applications, download large files, stream audio and video, exactly the same as how one would normally browse the internet.
Since the adapter attaches to your computers USB port, there is no need to have a [[3G]]/[[4G]] connection, you can simply use the wireless you already receive on your home or laptop computer.
==Who are the primary users?== *[http://www.hfield.com/the-wi-fire/who-uses-the-wi-fire/business-traveler/ Travelers for business] who need to stay connected with the office in airports, hotels, coffee shops, etc... while conducting business on the go. <sup>[http://www.hfield.com/the-wi-fire/who-uses-the-wi-fire/business-traveler/]</sup> *[http://www.hfield.com/the-wi-fire/who-uses-the-wi-fire/recreational-travelers/ Travelers for recreation] who want to keep in touch with family and friends while relaxing in a mobile home or on the beach, etc... <sup>[http://www.hfield.com/the-wi-fire/who-uses-the-wi-fire/recreational-travelers/<sup>]</sup> *[http://www.hfield.com/the-wi-fire/who-uses-the-wi-fire/students-universities/ Students] seeking a reliable way to connect to university hot spots, and access the internet they already pay for. <sup>[http://www.hfield.com/the-wi-fire/who-uses-the-wi-fire/students-universities/]</sup> *[http://www.hfield.com/the-wi-fire/who-uses-the-wi-fire/municipal-wi-fi/ Municipal] WiFi zone users who are unable to get a reliable signal. <sup>[http://www.hfield.com/the-wi-fire/who-uses-the-wi-fire/municipal-wi-fi/]</sup> *[http://www.hfield.com/the-wi-fire/who-uses-the-wi-fire/home-and-home-office/ Home and home-office users] who want more freedom at home to get online anywhere on their property, even outdoors. <sup>[http://www.hfield.com/the-wi-fire/who-uses-the-wi-fire/home-and-home-office/]</sup> *[http://www.hfield.com/the-wi-fire/who-uses-the-wi-fire/enterprise/ Office Managers] who are looking for a cost-effective way to give their employees better connectivity both in the office and on the road. <sup>[http://www.hfield.com/the-wi-fire/who-uses-the-wi-fire/enterprise/]</sup>

{{Infobox university | name= Egypt-Japan University of Science and Technology | native_name= '''الجامعة المصرية اليابانية للعلوم والتكنولوجيا''' | image_name= E-JUSTLogo.PNG | image_size= | caption= | motto= "Egyptian Research-Oriented University with Japanese Partnership" | established= February, 2010 | closed= | type= [[Special Status Governmental University]] | affiliation= | endowment= | officer_in_charge= | chairman= | acting president= Ahmed B. Khairy | vice-president= | provost= | vice_chancellor= | rector= | principal= | dean= | director= | head_label= | head= | faculty= | staff= | students= | undergrad= | postgrad= 30 | doctoral= | other= | city= [[New Borg El-Arab City]] | state= [[Alexandria]] | province= | country= [[Egypt]] | coor= | campus= | free_label= | free= | sports= | athletics= | affiliations= | website= [http://www.ejust.edu.eg/ www.ejust.edu.eg] | logo= | footnotes= }} '''Egypt-Japan University of Science and Technology (E-JUST)''' ({{lang-ar|الجامعة المصرية اليابانية للعلوم والتكنولوجيا}}, [[Arabic transliteration|transliteration]]: ''al-gāmaaʿa al-almāsreya al-alyābaneya lel ʿoloom wal toknologya ''), is a governmental [[Egypt]]ian university built in partnership with [[Japan]] in [[Borg El Arab|New Borg El-Arab City]] in [[Alexandria]] for graduate and undergraduate programs. It is established based on the mutual cooperation between the Egyptian and the Japanese governments for the purpose of having a long–standing partnership between the two countries to promote human development in the region and worldwide. Collaborating in growing and developing educational partnerships with Egyptian and Japanese universities, E-JUST enjoys a status of national and international recognition that enhances the exposure of its students to a mirage of best academic and research experiences.
==Programs== E-JUST is a preeminent research and teaching university with national and global reach, established under the Presidential Decree 149 in May 2009, and currently operating from the temporary location of Mubarak City for Scientific Research and Technology Applications (MuCSAT), the university serves the Egyptian Community, Arab World, and Africa with 7 programs of:
1. Electronics and Communications Engineering Program (ECE) ---- Spring 2010
2. Computer Science and Engineering Program (CSE) ---- Fall 2010
3. Mechatronics and Robotics Engineering Program (MTR ---- Spring 2010
4. Industrial Engineering and Management Systems Program (IEM) ---- Fall 2010
5. Materials Science and Engineering Program (MSE) ---- Spring 2011
6. Energy Resources and Environmental Engineering Program (EEE) ---- Spring 2010
7. Chemical and Petrochemicals Engineering Program (CPE) ---- Spring 2011
==History== [[Image:Bilateral Agreement.jpg|frame|right|H.E. Minister of International Cooperation [[Fayza Abu El-Naga]] & H.E. Ambassador of Japan in Egypt [[Kaoru Ishikawa]] signing the bilateral agreement for the establishment of E-JUST under the auspices of H.E. Prime Minister of Egypt [[Ahmed Nazif]] and H.E. Minister of Higher Education and State for Scientific Research [[Hany Helal]], March 2009]] Introduced as an idea during the Japan-Arab Dialogue Forum held in Tokyo in September 2003, passing by prolonged period of analysis and study, and under the auspices of Dr. Hany Hilal (Minister of Higher Education), Dr. Fayza Abu El-Naga (Minister of International Cooperation), and his Excellency Kaoru ISHIKAWA (Japan's Ambassador in Egypt), Egypt-Japan University of Science and Technology (E-JUST), is a research-oriented university with the vision of being a world-class educational institution.
Since then E-JUST has been passing with remarkable milestones that had great impact in shaping its foundation and educational identity:
'''August 2005:''' Submitting an initial proposal for establishing a Science and Technology University with Japanese partnership prepared by the Ministry of Higher Education and presented officially to Japan by the Ministries of International Cooperation and Foreign Affairs in Egypt.
'''September 2005:''' Formation of a Negotiating Egyptian Committee headed by Professor Galal Abdlhamid under the ministerial decision No. 1371 dated 30/9/2005.
'''March 2006:''' Egypt prepares a "Study Opportunity" and receives the first visit of a delegation representing the Japanese side to study and approve an official name of the university to be "Egypt-Japan University of Science and Technology, E-JUST".
'''January 2007:''' Studying the updated feasibility study and receiving a second expanded delegation visit of the Japanese side representing (Universities – Foreign Affairs – JICA) to Egypt.
'''April 2007:''' The first study of the joint technical and scientific committee in Tokyo and releasing the first "Joint Report".
'''May 2007:''' Their Excellencies, President of Egypt and Prime Minister of Japan declare the interests of both countries in establishing Egypt-Japan University in New Borg El-Arab City in an international press conference.
'''November 2007:''' Discussing the feasibility of establishing the University during the Japan-Arab conference in Bibliotheca Alexandria in the fifth bilateral meetings and plenary sessions with the participation of Japanese delegations as well as delegations of 15 Arab countries.
'''April 2008:''' An official delegation headed by the Minister of Japan's Scientific Research Policies visits Egypt for discussions on E-JUST establishment and research cooperation between the two countries.
'''April 2008:''' An official delegation representing leading Japanese universities, Ministry of Foreign Affairs and Japan International Cooperation Agency (JICA) visits Egypt to discuss all technical and scientific elements of the university.
'''June 2008:''' Signing a “Joint Minutes” of meetings between the Egyptian and Japanese sides on all basic articles for the university project.
'''June 2008:''' Japanese parliament officially adopts Japan's contribution to the establishment of Egypt-Japan University project in New Borg Al-Arab city while Japan International Cooperation Agency (JICA) begins its technical role of setting up the university.
'''July 2008:''' Experts from JICA in Tokyo visit Cairo to elaborate on the role of the agency in the next stage and starts procedures for the operational steps for the establishment of the university.
'''July 2008:''' Formation of the “Executive Committee” of the project headed by Professor Ahmed B. Khairy as a its president and a project manager under the ministerial decision No. 1674 dated 31/7/2008.
'''September 2008:''' Egyptian Cabinet approves the establishment of E-JUST
'''November 2008:''' The First Scientific symposium of the University was held at Bibliotheca Alexandrina in the presence of his Excellency Egypt's Minister of Higher Education and Japan's Deputy Minister of Foreign Affairs his Excellency Shibayama.
'''December 2008:''' Executive Committee visits Japan; Tokyo University, Waseda University, Kyoto University, Kyushu University and Osaka University.
'''February 2009:''' Declaring the final composition of the 12 Japanese Supporting Universities Coalition supporting E-JUST.
'''March 2009:''' Signature of the bilateral agreement between Egypt and Japan for the establishment of the university.
'''April 2009:''' Ratification of a scientific cooperation agreement between the E-JUST and the Environmental Nano-cluster Center of Kyoto University.
'''May 2009:''' Prof. Shirai - president of the Japanese universities coalition (consortium) visits E-JUST in New Borg El-Arab.
'''May 2009:''' Presidential Decree no. 149 on 29 May 2009, for endorsing the bilateral agreement between Egypt and Japan for establishing E-JUST; binding as an act by Egyptian constitution.
'''July 2009:''' Ministerial decision No. 1674 dated 31/7/2008 appointing professor Ahmed B. Khairy as Acting President for E-JUST.
'''October 2009:''' E-JUST signs a memorandum of understanding with Ain Shams University for the purpose of increasing human and professional relations which contribute to achieving the aims which both pursue.
'''February 11, 2010:''' First Board of Trustees meeting under the auspices of the Prime Minister of Egypt.
'''February 22, 2010:''' First Student intake in E-JUST History and start of the first academic semester in the temporary campus of Mubarak City of scientific Research and Technology applications (MuCSAT).
==Vision== To be a world class leading university in science and technology
'''Short Term – 5 Years: '''
To establish the foundation of high quality education and research;
To participate in and contribute to the network of science and technology in Egypt;
To establish linkage with industry;
To promote relationship between Japan and Egypt.
'''Medium Term – 10 Years: '''
To strengthen the network of Arab countries, Africa and Asia in science and technology;
To consolidate the foundation of high quality of education and research;
To shoulder social responsibility.
'''Long Term – 15 Years: '''
To contribute to Egypt’s nation-building;
To create seeds for effective collaboration between academia and industry in Egypt;
To produce top leaders for promoting economic and social development.
==Mission== 1. To become a role model for postgraduate education and research institutions in Egypt;
2. To have academic degrees with a status of international recognition and accreditation by Japanese, local and international accrediting bodies;
3. To contribute to the enhancement of human resources in the region;
4. To promote strong business, technical and commercial ties between Japanese industries and organizations and their counterparts in countries and regions served by E-JUST.
==Basic Concepts of E-JUST== [[Image:Softopening.jpg|frame|right|E-JUST Soft Opening, September 2009]] -->
1. First-class, leading university to serve Egypt, Arab World, Africa;
2. Research-oriented, graduate-focused university
3. Japanese style approach (Lab-based education, practical & problem solving oriented, teamwork spirit)
4. Unique academic programs (close interaction with industry and society, multidisciplinary, ICT utilization)
5. National university based on partnership between Egypt and Japan
6. Role model for Egypt’s 21st Century universities
==Why E-JUST?== With the purpose of having a long standing partnership between Egypt and Japan, E-JUST has been established to promote human development in the region and worldwide as well as playing a leading role in the reformation of research in Egypt in addition to building partnerships with key Japanese academic and research institutions and industrial companies for conducting applied research.
- E-JUST will work on exposing the students and faculty to real life research activities, and getting them acquainted with the Japanese systems and technical know how.
- E-JUST aims to implement cutting-edge educational systems based on Japanese academic concepts founded on project-based and problem based learning while introducing modern and advanced interdisciplinary academic programs.
- E-JUST brings Japan with its scientific and technological achievements to the Egyptian community with a long enthusiastic vision of contributing to Egypt's nation building.
- E-JUST will foster all efforts on promoting multidisciplinary team work skills in addition to building strong mechanisms with the local and regional industries.
==Faculties== At present stage, E-JUST is structured into two faculties and four centers of excellence following the Japanese model of graduate focused universities;
'''Faculty of Engineering, including 3 schools:'''
1- School of Electronics, Communications and Computer Engineering including Department of Electronics and Communications Engineering and Department of Computer Science and Engineering.
2- School of Innovative Design Engineering including Department of Mechatronics and Robotics Engineering, Department of Industrial Engineering and Management Systems, Department of Materials Science and Engineering
3- School of Energy and Environmental Engineering including Department of Energy Resources and Environmental Engineering and Department of Chemical and Petrochemical Engineering
'''Faculty of Business and Humanities, including 2 schools:'''
1- School of International Business and Management Systems including Department of International Business and Department of Management Systems.
2- School of Cross Culture Studies including Department of Egyptology and Department of Japanese studies.
==Centers of Excellence== 1. Nano-Science and Engineering Research Center
2. Energy Resources and Management Research Center
3. Electronics / Mechatronics Research Center
4. High Tech Training and Continuing Education Center
==Campus Site== Living and learning are intimately related at E-JUST. Extended on 840,000 square meters in the New Industrial City of Borg El-Arab, E-JUST Campus allows scholars to find more to college life than just attending classes.
E-JUST enjoys a distinct location that enables dedicated academic researchers to fully engage in a high-tech community with relevance to the practical world. The campus will be extended approximately 53 Km south-west of Alexandria next doors to an area with growing research and educational facilities such as Mubarak City for Scientific Research and Technology Applications (MuCSAT) as well as being close to the industrial zones of Borg El-Arab city, the expansions of Alexandria University and Bibliotheca Alexandrina., in addition to futuristic potentials of 500,000 inhabitants, an international airport, and a rapid metro system linking to Alexandria.
The campus will represent state-of-the-art technologies of the 21st Century, while reflecting Egyptian and Japanese cultural values and identities. Intending to serve the university’s educational mission, while promoting interaction with the community at large, the campus will include:
1-Academic Facilities;
2-Administration Buildings;
3-Students Services;
4-Facility Center; [retail shops, clinic, academic unions, mosque/chapel]
5-Residential District;
6-Centers of Excellence;
7-Club & Sports Facilities; [clubhouse, gymnasium, indoor sports center, sports arena, outdoor playing grounds]
8-Central Library;
9-Research Support & Media Centers; [Instrumental Analysis Center, Environmental Safety Training Center, Media Center]
10-Community Center; [Industrial Support Center, Convention Center & Auditorium]
11-Visitors Center; [Arts Center, Exhibition Center]
12-E-JUST Science Gallery and Park.
==Temporary Location== [[Image:Openingceremony.jpg|frame|right|E-JUST Acting President [[Prof. Ahmed Khairy]] & Chairman of E-JUST Board of Trustess [[Yousry El-Gamal]] with E-JUST first student batch, academic and administrative staff at the university's soft opening ceremony, February 20, 2010]] -->
Mubarak City for Scientific Research & Technology Applications (Muscat) [http://www.mcsrta.sci.eg/] is the newest addition of research institutes in Egypt that was directed to the development and renovation of industry. Muscat is managed by a board of trustee headed by his Excellency Dr. Mofied Shehab, Scientific Research Minster.
A decision to develop a science park in Alexandria was reached in 1993 in order to acquire and improve scientific technologies in different areas of human life. Muscat occupies 250 acres in the industrial area located at New Borg El Arab City, west of Alexandria. This region also inhabits about 40% of the Egyptian industry. The science park comprises 12 research centers to be developed at different intervals. The first stage of Muscat was inaugurated on August 13, 2000 including Genetic Engineering and Biotechnology Research Institute (GEBRI), Informatics Research Institute (IRI) and Institute of Advanced Technologies and New Materials (IATNM). In addition, a Technology Capabilities Development Center is fully functioning in the Dekhlia Branch. Muscat is engrossed to both scientific researches in addition to the application of technologies. This is the foremost spirit that distinguishes the city from other scientific research in Egypt. Moreover, the technology centers in the city are unique in their aim to spread the modern technology application and to provide training in order to help serve its role in developing the Egyptian community.
==Campus Architectural Competition== E-JUST launched an International Architectural Competition started May 2009 and concluded December 2009 among Egyptian and Japanese architectural firms to compete over designing the university campus, a creative design that will reflect the economic, social, and cultural value systems of Egypt and Japan.
The Competition was divided into two phases: Prequalification, and Shortlisted Applicants. Prequalification was concluded in August 2009, selecting 12 finalists from top architectural firms in Egypt and Japan among 75 participants, while the 3 top winners were selected in December 2009 as: Arata Isozaki and Associates Co. LTD (First Prize) [http://www.isozaki.co.jp], Hiroshi Hara / Hiroshi Hara + ATELIER •Φ- Kazuhiro Kojima / C+A, Coelacanth & Associates (Second Prize) [[Hiroshi Hara (architect)]], and Fujimoto Architects (Third Prize).

'''GestureTek''' is an American-based interactive technology company headquartered in [[Silicon Valley]], [[California]], with offices in [[Toronto]] and [[Ottawa]], [[Ontario]] and [[Asia]].<ref>http://www.gesturetek.com/</ref> Founded in 1986 by Canadians Vincent John Vincent<ref>http://www.vjvincent.com/</ref> and Francis MacDougall<ref>http://www.techthink.org/speaker08_MacDougall.asp</ref>, this privately-held company develops and licenses [[gesture recognition]] software based on [[computer vision]] techniques. The partners invented video gesture control in 1986 and received their base [[patent]] in 1996 for the GestPoint video gesture control system. GestPoint technology is a camera-enabled [[video tracking]] software system that translates hand and body movement into computer control.<ref>http://edition.cnn.com/2009/TECH/ptech/04/23/cnet.touch.screens/</ref> The system enables users to navigate and control interactive multi-media and menu-based content, engage in virtual reality game play, experience [[immersion]] in an [[augmented reality]] environment or interact with a consumer device (such a television, mobile phone or set top box) without using touch-based peripherals. <ref>http://www.engadget.com/2009/01/05/gesturetek-brings-3d-and-gestures-together-for-remote-control/</ref><ref>http://www.crunchgear.com/2008/11/12/watch-out-surface-gesturetek-is-straight-frontin/</ref><ref>http://mobileworldcongress.mediaroom.com/index.php?s=43&item=361</ref>
GestureTek’s gesture interface applications include multi-touch and 3D camera tracking. GestureTek’s [[multi-touch]] technology powers the multi-touch table in Melbourne’s [[Eureka Tower]]<ref>http://www.aboutmicrosoftsurface.com/microsoft-surface-versus-gesturetek-illuminate-table.php</ref>. A GestureTek multi-touch table with [[object recognition]] is found at the New York City Visitors Center<ref>http://svconline.com/corporateav/features/new_york_information_center_409/</ref>. Telefonica has a [[multi-touch]] window with technology from GestureTek<ref>http://deals.venturebeat.com/2007/12/12/gesturetek-receives-investment-from-telefonica/</ref>. GestureTek’s 3D tracking technology is used in a [[3D television]] prototype from Hitachi and various digital signage and display solutions based on 3D interaction<ref>http://www.lcdtvreviews.org.uk/lcd-news/hitachi-gesturetek-collaboration-to-realise-bare-hand-tv-remote-control/</ref>.
GestureTek currently has 8 patents awarded, including: 5,534,917<ref>http://www.freepatentsonline.com/5534917.html?query=PN%2F5534917+OR+5534917&stemming=on</ref> (Video Gesture Control Motion Detection); 7,058,204 <ref>http://www.freepatentsonline.com/7058204.html</ref> (Multiple Camera Control System, Point to Control Base Patent); 7,421,093 <ref>http://www.freepatentsonline.com/7421093.html</ref> (Multiple Camera Tracking System for Interfacing With an Application); 7,227,526 <ref>http://www.patentstorm.us/patents/7227526.html</ref> (Stereo Camera Control, 3D-Vision Image Control System); 7,379,563 <ref>http://www.patentstorm.us/patents/7379563.html</ref> (Two Handed Movement Tracker Tracking Bi-Manual Movements); 7,379,566 <ref>http://www.patentgenius.com/patent/7379566.html</ref> (Optical Flow-Based Tilt Sensor For Phone Tilt Control); 7,389,591 <ref>http://www.freepatentsonline.com/7389591.html</ref> (Phone Tilt for Typing & Menus/Orientation-Sensitive Signal Output); 7,430,312 <ref>http://www.freepatentsonline.com/7430312.html</ref> (Five Camera 3D Face Capture).
GestureTek’s software and patents have been licensed by [[Microsoft]] for the [[XBOX 360]]<ref>http://www.gamasutra.com/php-bin/news_index.php?story=11215</ref>, [[Sony]] for the EyeToy<ref>http://findarticles.com/p/articles/mi_m0EIN/is_2005_Feb_18/ai_n9546647/?tag=content;col1</ref>, NTT DoCoMo for their mobile phones<ref>http://iq4m.com/Track_Record.html</ref> and [[Hasbro]] for the ION Educational Gaming System<ref>http://www.gamasutra.com/news/mobile-phone/?story=17395</ref>. In addition to software provision, GestureTek also fabricates interactive gesture control display systems with [[natural user interface]] for interactive advertising, games and presentations. <ref>http://www.digitalsignagetoday.com/video_gallery.php?v=1586</ref>
In addition, GestureTek’s natural user interface virtual reality system has been the subject of research by universities and hospitals for its application in both [[physical therapy]]<ref>http://www.pubmedcentral.nih.gov/articlerender.fcgi?artid=546410</ref> and [[physical rehabilitation]]<ref>http://hw.haifa.ac.il/occupa/LIRT/vr.htm. Retrieved on 2009-05-07</ref>.
In 2008, GestureTek received the Mobile Innovation Global Award<ref>http://www.wirelessweek.com/Article-FirstNews_February13_2008.aspx </ref> from the GSMA for its software-based, gesture-controlled user interface for mobile games and applications. The technology is used by Java platform integration providers<ref>http://www.aplixcorp.com/en/release/pdf/20080630.pdf</ref> and mobile developers<ref>http://www.gamezone.com/news/12_19_08_11_48AM.htm</ref>. [[Katamari Damacy]] is one example of a gesture control mobile game powered by GestureTek software.
